items.title: Add FAQ entry on how to load exteral python files
items.body:
The following questions come often, and we should add create a FAQ in the documentation and add it there.

Approximate questions and answers below, but they might need to be adjusted.

### How can I load external python files in Pyodide?

The two possible solutions are, 
  - include these files into a python package, build a pure python wheel and load [it with micropip](https://pyodide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pypi.html#installing-wheels-from-arbitrary-urls).
  - by fetching the python code as a string and running eval on it https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/issues/417#issuecomment-490210764

In both cases, files need to be served with a web server (for instance using `python -m http.server`) and not from the local file system directly.

### Why can't I load files from the local file system directly?

For security reasons javascript in the browser is not allowed to load local data files. You need to serve them with a web-browser.

*Note:* there is a workaround in https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/pull/606 but it's unlikely to be included in the main pyodide distribution.

items.title: Add script to update package versions
items.body:
Similarly to `pyodide_build/mkpkg.py` it would be useful to have some script that would fetch latest metadata from PyPi and update the version number, sha256 digest and download URL in an existing `meta.yaml`.
```
pyodide_build/update_pkg.py meta.yaml
```

Something like this already exists in conda-forge, since there is a bot that auto-updates recipes in https://github.com/regro/cf-scripts but the questions is whether it would be easier to try to adapt it or write something very easy specifically for pyodide.

In any case it would be good to have some semi-automated way to keep packages up to date.

**Edit:** there was an earlier attempt in https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/pull/569

items.title: Fix test_install_custom_url timing issues
items.body:
Currently `test_install_custom_url` often fails particularly on chrome,
```py
    def test_install_custom_url(selenium_standalone, web_server_secondary):
        server_hostname, server_port, server_log = web_server_secondary
        selenium_standalone.load_package("micropip")
        selenium_standalone.run("import micropip")
        base_url = f'http://{server_hostname}:{server_port}/test/data/'
        url = base_url + 'snowballstemmer-2.0.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl'
        selenium_standalone.run(f"micropip.install('{url}')")
>       selenium_standalone.run("import snowballstemmer")
...
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'snowballstemmer'
```

The issue is that `micropip.install('{url}')` returns a promise and sometimes doesn't complete before the next line is run, similarly to https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/issues/695

items.title: Add package FreeSASA to not cripple BioPython
items.body:
In protein bioinformatics, the solvent-accessible surface area of protein residues is a greatly important metric for protein analysis.
However, the most widely used libraries such as DSSP, NACCESS, and etc mostly have limitations in license usage or are close-sourced. 
Thus in the Bio.PDB subpackage of BioPython, while it did implement a wrapper to these programs, it did not include the programs that are supposed to run the backend of the wrapper. This, therefore, cripples the BioPython package in Pyodide significantly.
Luckily, an open-source version that calculates the solvent-accessible surface area called [FreeSASA](https://github.com/freesasa/freesasa-python) and its [PyPi](https://pypi.org/project/freesasa/) package can [complement the Bio.PDB](http://freesasa.github.io/python/intro.html#bio-pdb) package's problem, but it cannot be installed using micropip because there is not a pure python wheel, and must be installed using the tar.gz source file because it has C++ in the package.
Therefore I ask pyodide devs to implement this package for BioPython users to leverage at its maximum.

 - relax flake8 to only check syntax errors, unused variables and imports.

These can also run locally with a pre-commit setup.

items.title: pyodide.cdn.iodide.io is quite slow
items.body:
The current hosting of packages is at https://pyodide.cdn.iodide.io seems to capped at ~600kB/s¹ which means that 15MB of pandas takes 25s to download. That's a very long time. 

```
curl -X GET pyodide.cdn.iodide.io/pandas.data -o out.whl 
% Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100 14.8M  100 14.8M    0     0   564k      0  0:00:26  0:00:26 --:--:--  602k
```

The hostname  pyodide.cdn.iodide.io  maps via a CNAME entry to `pyodide.netlify.com.`, so it sounds like the limitation is Netlify's end. Could it be because we have used the allotted 100GB of traffic per month or is it just their default limitation for free accounts?

¹at least for me in France with a 60+ MB/s wired connection

**Edit:** I also get similar speeds in a browser in case they are filtering by User-Agent.

items.title: Make CORS proxy in micropip configurable
items.body:
We currently use the cors-anywhere.herokuapp.com / https://github.com/Rob--W/cors-anywhere CORS proxy to load packages from PyPi, that is hardcoded in
https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/blob/c9fd3e1d572354113ca57351a09c09c872ba0f56/packages/micropip/micropip/micropip.py#L96

Because using a third party proxy can have security concerns, we should make it optionally configurable e.g.,
```py
import micropip
micropip.set_proxy("https://yacdn.org/serve/")
micropip.install('snowballstemmer')
```
so that users can change it if needed.

items.title: Release 0.15.0
items.body:
There have been a few improvements on master since 0.14.3 last December and it would be nice to make a new release with it. Since we changed CPython version 3.7.0 to 3.7.4 we can increment the minor version to 0.15.0 (or otherwise make it 0.14.4). 

@mdboom To make a new release is 
 - updating the [changelog](https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md)
 - creating a tag on master to deploy to netlify
 - updating `__version__` in `src/pyodide.py`

sufficient? Or are there other manual steps I missed?

items.title: micropip: support arbitrary URLs for wheels
items.body:
For third party packages that are not necessarily on PyPi, it would we nice if micropip supported arbitrary URLs for wheels, e.g. 
```
%% py
import micropip
micropip.install('http://<some-url>py3-none-any.whl')
```
Assuming this wheel has no dependencies (or that they are manually loaded) this should be fairly straightforward I think.

It would also address part of use case of https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/pull/489, as one could just take a python module make a wheel out of it and load it with micropip. Ths would have the advantage of wheels being a standard interface for installable python packages/modules.

**Edit:** somewhat related to https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/issues/121 as well.

I'll try to look into it.

items.title: Compiling a package with libraries
items.body:
Is there a recommended way to compile a new package that uses external libraries that are not provided by emscripten or the ports (such as glib)?

I suppose I could compile these to bitcode separately and then pass a linker flag in the `meta.yaml` to link that along, but that seems like a hack.

items.title: Allow for selectively building packages
items.body:
The [build instructions](https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide#building-from-source) only specify how to build pyodide together with all of the packages it includes by default. As a result you have to build all of the packages even if you only intend to use a single one, or if you only intend to build a custom package without using any of the default ones.

Would it be difficult to add a way to only build the packages you intend to use?

items.title: Would it be feasible to use numba inside pyodide or make something similar?
items.body:
The user's python script running in pyodide is still interpreted instead of compiled. The speed is extremely slow when running for loops of millions times. 
In desktop's python I use numba to just-in-time compile a specific loop-intensive function.
Would it be feasible to implement numba package for pyodide or native support of compiling user's code with a decorator similar to numba.njit?

items.title: C++ exceptions not working as expected
items.body:
I am working on porting a project to run in Pyodide. My progress can be found here: https://github.com/johnwason/robotraconteur_pyodide . Because this project depends on Boost, CMake, and SWIG it can't be easily packaged using setuptools. Instead an external CMake build is used.

While testing, I discovered that C++ exceptions were not being caught. It appears that if a function throws an exception, it is not propagated to the calling function's catch handler. I was able to reproduce the problem in a toy problem: https://gist.github.com/johnwason/422b0bd9787088db3d12b422a6a835ff . Run `build.sh`, then in the `console.html` of pyodide run

    import pyodide_exception_test_module
    pyodide_exception_test_module.test_exceptions(0)

Looking at the browser debug console output, this seems to silently fail to handle the exception thrown in `test_exception2()`. It should catch the exception and propagate it to python through `PyErr_SetString`. If the exception is thrown within `test_exception()`, it works as expected.

Why am I seeing this behavior, and is there a way to correct it?

I had to use this patch to load the modules  https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/issues/507, not sure if that is affecting anything.

items.title: pyodide seems to crash iOS browsers (safari and chrome)
Contributing Packages
items.body:
I've got a few packages with C dependencies python that I'm interested in using to port an existing Python project to the web. I was wondering if you guys are interested in me cleaning them up and upstreaming them.

## [regex](https://pypi.org/project/regex/)
Pretty simple, it doesn't have any external dependencies, so it Just Worked<sup>TM</sup>.

Branch here: https://github.com/fallaciousreasoning/pyodide/tree/compile-python-regex

## [lxml](https://pypi.org/project/lxml/)
More complicated. Has a dependency on libxml and libxslt. This adds a not insignificant chunk of time to the initial build. Not sure how widely used this is or whether you'd be interested in it here.

Maybe we need some kind of opt-in for building dependencies, or a system like [emscripten-ports](https://emscripten.org/docs/compiling/Building-Projects.html#emscripten-ports)? It doesn't seem sustainable to add everything here.

Branch here: https://github.com/fallaciousreasoning/pyodide/tree/compile-python-lxml

**Note:** It's not finished yet, but I have the lxml package building /woot/. Also, I have no idea what I'm doing so there are (many) things I'm almost certainly doing the wrong way.

## [html5-parser](https://pypi.org/project/html5-parser/)
Depends on lxml, not started.

## [Pillow](https://pypi.org/project/Pillow/)
I initially started by trying to port this, but it seemed kind of complicated, so I started looking at the other packages to try and work up to it. Suspect that this will be the most interesting to Pyodide.

--------------------

Just wanted to end by saying you guys are doing some awesome stuff, keep up the good work!

items.title: Boolean check on JavaScript 'Event' object results in False
items.body:
Hi there,

I'm unable to boolean check on a JavaScript Event object:
```python
>>> from js import eval as jseval
>>> e = jseval("new Event('change')")
>>> e
[object Event]
>>> bool(e)
false
```

The reason for this is in the implementation of the [JsProxyType](https://github.com/iodide-project/pyodide/blob/master/src/jsproxy.c#L409), where `__bool__` is not defined and falls back to `__len__`, but `len(e)` returns 0 in this case. It works well for other JavaScript objects, e.g. `Array`, or even `window`.

Any suggestions how this can be solved?

get/env[prop]()@https://pyodide.cdn.iodide.io/pyodide.asm.js:8:9106
{anonymous}()@https://pyodide.cdn.iodide.io/pyodide.asm.js line 8 > WebAssembly.Module:wasm-function[214]:0xafb7

...
```

I ran into the same issue when running the notebook in a local pyodide build. I grep'ed for `Module[prop]` and found it in the middle of `pyodide.asm.js` as `...Module["setThrew"](1,0)}}}return env[prop]=function(){return Module[prop].apply(null,arguments)}}};var info={global:{"NaN":NaN,Infinity:Infinity}...` So I manually edited it from `function(){return Module[prop].apply(null,arguments)}` -> `function(){}` and that made the issue go away locally. But of course I still have the same issue on https://alpha.iodide.io.

items.title: Release caching
items.body:
Would it be possible to have each release have all its respective files (such as pyodide.js) and all the other related files marked with their respective version and build number? That way the server could set browser caching to something drastic like 1 year, and it is guaranteed that pyodide-0.13.0.js will never change so that caching is not an issue. Users just then need to manually point to the pyodide js file that matches the version they want to use.

Another example of this in practice. Let's say numpy is at version 1.16.4. Its js and data files would look like numpy-1.16.4_0.js etc. And the respective pyodide-0.13.0.js would point to that specific numpy path. Let's say we don't upgrade the version of numpy, but the wasm build of numpy has been optimised or changed, that final build number allows us to bust the cache for that case. So pyodide-0.13.0.js would still point to numpy-1.16.4_0.js but pyodide-0.13.1.js would point to numpy-1.16.4_1.js (with the build number iterated).

Let me know your thoughts.

Cheers,
Simon

items.title: Pyodide Tutorial at PyCon LT Help Needed
items.body:
I will be offering a tutorial on Pyodide at PyCon LT May 25th or 26th in Vilnius Lithuania. 

If any of the senior Pyodide developers will be there I would be grateful if you would attend to answer any of the questions which are beyond me. 

If you are new to Pyodide, and would like to learn how ot use it, as opposed to how to develop it, I invite you to attend my tutorial. Here is an updated description. 

Learn how to use Python's Data Science libraries, running in the browser. After an brief talk about Python in the browser, we learn how to use Python and Javascript together to fetch data, to calculate and to display results.

Iodide/Pyodide, offered by Mozilla, is like Jupyter Notebooks, but the optional cPython kernel runs in the browser, compiled to Web Assembly. All that is needed is a file server, and a web browser, no compute server is required. This is particularly good for schools, and web apps, so that the servers do not get overloaded by thousands of users. Pyodide already has a rich collection of Python libraries compiled to Web Assembly. 32 as of last week, certainly all the ones which I need.

It is best to develop web applications using a combination of Python and Javascript. We learn how to use Python in the browser, import data and libraries and calculate results. We learn how to communicate bidirectionally between Python and Javascript to calculate and display results. We plot things from both Javascript and Python. We learn the difference between the browser console and the Iodide console. We exercise all the different types of cells. Markdown, Python, Javascript, Raw, Fetch and CSS. We also build a simple web app using Pyodide without Iodide.

By the end of the tutorial the student should be comfortable using the basic tools, and be ready to begin their own custom projects.

Would something like `pyodide._module.FS.writeFile` followed by plain `import X` work?

items.title: Time module in standard lib
items.body:
Hi,

first of all, thanks for the great project. This is all massively impressive.

I have been tinkering around with pyodide for a while and it seems that I can't get python `time` module to work. For example, `pyodide.runPythonAsync('import time\ntime.sleep(10)\nprint(5)')` returns immediately (with 5 being correctly printed), but I would expect it to resolve after 10 seconds.

I was wondering if I am doing something wrong or if this functionality is not yet supported.

Best,
Jan

items.title: How to add the figure to a html page which generated by matplotlib?
items.body:
Hi, I would like to call pyodide.js manually. Then insert the output to my html page.

For Python command line output. I can call `pyodide.runPython('import sys;\nsys.version')` to  get the output. Then add it to an element's inerHTML.But for the figure which generated by `matplotlib`, how can I get the element and  add it to html document?

Edit: When matplotlib rendering the result, it report `iodide.output` is `NoneType`. Maybe I need to configure it in somewhere or someway?

Thanks!
